newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korea Kim urges legislation implementing reform.
newsitem.headline: S.Korea Kim urges legislation implementing reform.

text.p: South Korean President Kim Young-sam on Tuesday urged the Finance and Economy Minister to prepare legislation implementing financial reforms proposed by a presidential reform panel.
The Presidential Commission for Financial Reform was due to present today proposals to Kim to modernise the nation's backward financial industry.

"I hope the Finance Minister would prepare the government's reform bills based on the proposals and discuss them with political parties," Kim said in a meeting with members of the commission, the finance minister and heads of the central bank and financial supervisory boards.
"I would like the Finance Minister to submit legislation to this coming parliamentary session for adoption," he said.

Kim said the proposals contained long-pending but difficult issues including the central bank's independence, revision of the financial supervisory board system and changes in ownership of financial institutions.
"I believe the commission proposals are substantial and are on the right track," Kim said.
Kim said the financial industry faced a global tide of integration, increased autonomy and efficiency.

"First of all, the central bank should be independent and its status should be enhanced so that it can implement monetary policy neutrally," he said. But the bank must be fully aware of its duties, including its role in curbing inflation, he said..
The 31-member presidential panel was to propose a single unified financial supervisory board to oversee the banking, securities and insurance industries.
"Given the global trend towards lowering barriers within the financial industry, the commission's proposal for a unified financial watchdog agency is heading in the right direction," Kim said.
Each government agency involved in macro-economic management, monetary policy and supervision should work independently but cooperatively, he said.

"Eventually, these reforms should clarify and increase the efficiency of the roles, links and responsibilities of financial authorities such as the Finance Ministry, the central bank and supervisory boards," he said.
